title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and provides a basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, to specify that specific information from a credible source must be received within 15 days for the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. The Attorney General must act within 15 days upon receiving specific information to determine if there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law. If evidence is insufficient, the matter is closed; if evidence is sufficient, a preliminary investigation begins. If unable to decide within 15 days, a preliminary investigation starts regardless. 28, United States Code, amended to require specific information from a credible source for the Attorney General to determine if there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel under title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify limitations to alleged criminal law violations and related matters. The independent counsel is granted authority to fully investigate and prosecute within defined prosecutorial jurisdiction. The independent counsel is granted adequate authority to investigate and prosecute alleged violations of criminal law, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. Amendments specify limitations to prosecutorial jurisdiction. The independent counsel is granted authorities and duties to investigate and prosecute alleged violations of criminal law. The independent counsel is provided with office space within a Federal building by the Administrator of General Services, unless other arrangements are more cost-effective. Amendments are made to ensure compliance with Department of Justice policies regarding the enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information related to criminal proceedings. Amendments are made to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code, repealing prior amendments. A limitation on expenditures for the operation of any office of independent counsel is set, with funds only available for up to 2 years unless specified in an appropriations Act. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow removal of independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to allow termination of an independent counsel office by the court under certain conditions. The petition can be made more than 2 years after the appointment of independent counsel, based on the completion of the investigation or if it's not in the public interest. An independent counsel must report monthly expenditures to specified committees. The amendment regarding the effective date of the independent counsel appointment shall take effect after the enactment of the Act. Section 596 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for periodic reappointment of independent counsel every 2 years. The court will reappoint the applicant if deemed appropriate, otherwise appoint another qualified person within 90 days. If no action is taken within this period, the office of independent counsel will terminate. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act, with recommendations to improve cost controls for offices of independent counsel under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
